story.text: When we think of [[innovation]], we think of a lone inventor in a garage.  Possibly a [[researcher]] working at a university, or perhaps the research activities undertaken by a [[private company]]. That is we think of something that happens within a bounded space, that is the bounds of an individual [[legal person]].
Our [[current systems]] are based around this simplified idea of innovation.

Open innovation, on the other hand, involves breaking down these [[institutional barriers]], enabling ideas to [[flow]] across [[organisational borders]] - accelerating the pace and reducing the [[cost of innovation]].
[[Secure distributed ledgers]], of the sort provided by blockchain technology can provide a means for protecting and governing the flow of ideas across such institutional barriers.
Software in the form of [[smart contracts]] can reduce the administrative costs associated with allocating [[value]] to [[complex]] assemblages of ideas into new products and services.
Indeed blockchain enables us to create entirely new forms of [[intellectual property]] regime, designed for a better fit for the modern world.
What is needed is an [[ecosystem]] of open innovation, supported by a technological platform that enables modern, complex forms of [[interdisciplinary collaboration]] - at as low a cost as possible.

An open innovation ecosystem would therefore involve many [[stakeholders]], including lone [[inventors]], [[scientists]], public and private [[funders]], small [[companies]] and large [[multinationals]].

Such an [[ecosystem]] is [[complex]]. This complexity needs to be supported by a [[technical platform]] that is able to reduce the costs - in particular the [[legal costs]] associated with complex [[intellectual property]] arrangements.

The [[technical platform]] that supports open innovation needs to be governed on behalf of all [[stakeholders]]. Due to [[privacy]] and security concerns organisations will wish to run their own servers, and [[control]] their own data.

A centralised solution will not satisfy the needs of organisation or individuals. We need a flexible [[secure distributed ledger]] which can scale, and evolve alongside the [[growing demands]] of its [[stakeholders]].
